message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Current Applications of Game Theory in Construction Engineering and Management Research: A Social Network Analysis Approach
Paper Abstract: Game theory provides a rigorous mathematical approach to evaluate and predict stakeholders' interactions. Even though the construction industry is rich with encounters among its stakeholders, construction engineering and management (CEM) research lacks a thorough investigation of game-theoretic applications. This paper presents an overview of the current game-theoretic models in CEM research, aiming to enhance the understanding of the applications of game theory in analyzing CEM strategic interactions within multiple application domains and project delivery systems (PDSs). The authors analyzed 87 CEM peer-reviewed publications employing game-theoretic models between 1998 and 2019. The analysis accounted for CEM application domain, involvement of stakeholders, PDS addressed, and type of game theoretic solution used in each publication. The authors performed a Social Network Analysis (SNA) of the current game-theoretic interactions, identifying literature trends and gaps to be addressed in future research. Unlike traditional literature review methods, SNA provides a quantitative approach in analyzing the existing body of knowledge. Research findings demonstrate the contributions of game theory in seven CEM applications (conflict resolution; bargaining and negotiations; allocation of cooperative benefits; governance and supervision; evolution of cooperation and trust; construction bidding; and risk allocation). Through SNA, the highest degree centrality levels were found in Owner-Contractor games in the context of CEM bidding, conflict resolution, as well as bargaining and negotiations. SNA also revealed the need for further investigation of interactions among CEM stakeholders within PDS other than the traditional Design-Bid-Build and Public-Private-Partnerships. Moreover, games featuring strategic alliances and supply chains of multiagents can provide more adequate reflections of actual interactions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about construction management:

## Definition and Core Focus

Construction management focuses on integrating cost, schedule, quality, safety, and scope throughout the project lifecycle.(no content)Unlike a general contractor, a CM firm or professional may be engaged as an owner's representative to advise during feasibility, design, procurement, and construction.

## Education and Professional Development

CM is taught in associate, bachelor's, master's, and doctoral programs.(no content)Accreditation bodies include ABET, the American Council for Construction Education (ACCE), and the Associated Schools of Construction (ASC).

## Professional Organizations

The Construction Management Association of America (CMAA) is a non-profit and non-governmental, professional association serving the construction management industry, formed in 1982.(no content)CMAA established a voluntary certification program for construction managers, known as the Certified Construction Manager (CCM) program.

## Technology Tools

Construction and capital project management software (CPMS) help manage budgets, schedules, documents, and collaboration.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Risk Management allocation"

Links: [{"title":"Risk parity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_parity"},{"title":"Financial risk management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_risk_management"},{"title":"RiskMetrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RiskMetrics"},{"title":"Risk management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_management"},{"title":"Risk-adjusted return on capital - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk-adjusted_return_on_capital"},{"title":"Asset allocation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_allocation"},{"title":"Asset and liability management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_and_liability_management"},{"title":"Risk management plan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_management_plan"},{"title":"Max Abrahamson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Abrahamson"},{"title":"Risk Management Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_Management_Framework"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Risk Management allocation:

## Overview

Risk management is the identification, evaluation, and prioritization of risks, followed by the minimization, monitoring, and control of the impact or probability of those risks occurring.

## Capital Allocation in Risk Management

In financial institutions, risk management allocation is closely tied to capital allocation. For risk management purposes, the main goal of allocating capital to individual business units is to determine the bank's optimal capital structure—that is economic capital allocation is closely correlated with individual business risk.(no content)Risk-adjusted return on capital (RAROC) is a risk-based profitability measurement framework for analysing risk-adjusted financial performance and providing a consistent view of profitability across businesses.

## Risk Prioritization

When allocating resources to manage risks, a prioritization process is typically followed, whereby the risks with the greatest loss (or impact) and the greatest probability of occurring are handled first, with risks of lower probability and lower loss handled in descending order.

## Alternative Approaches

In investment management, risk parity is an approach to investment management which focuses on allocation of risk, usually defined as volatility, rather than allocation of capital.

Web search results for query: "Negotiation"

Links: [{"title":"Negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negotiation"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Negotiation"},{"title":"Negotiation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negotiation_theory"},{"title":"Automated negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_negotiation"},{"title":"Program on Negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_on_Negotiation"},{"title":"List of books about negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_books_about_negotiation"},{"title":"Leverage (negotiation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leverage_(negotiation)"},{"title":"Bargaining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bargaining"},{"title":"Harvard Negotiation Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_Negotiation_Project"},{"title":"Strategic Negotiations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_Negotiations"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about negotiation:

## Definition

Negotiation is a dialogue between two or more parties to resolve points of difference, gain an advantage for an individual or collective, or craft outcomes to satisfy various interests.

## Common Applications

People negotiate daily, often without considering it a negotiation. Negotiations may occur in organizations, including businesses, non-profits, and governments, as well as in sales and legal proceedings, and personal situations such as marriage, divorce, parenting, friendship, etc.

## Professional Negotiators

Examples of professional negotiators include union negotiators, leverage buyout negotiators, peace negotiators, and hostage negotiators.

## Negotiation Theory

Negotiation is a specialized and formal version of conflict resolution, most frequently employed when important issues must be agreed upon. Negotiation is necessary when one party requires the other party's agreement to achieve its aim.

## Types of Leverage

There are three types of leverage: positive leverage, negative leverage, and normative leverage. Positive leverage is a negotiator's ability to provide things that his or her opponent wants. Negative leverage is a threat-based form of leverage that represents one side's ability to make the other side worse off. Normative leverage relies on using social standards or norms to encourage consensus.

## Bargaining Approaches

Integrative bargaining (also called "interest-based bargaining," "win-win bargaining") is a negotiation strategy in which parties collaborate to find a "win-win" solution to their dispute. This strategy focuses on developing mutually beneficial agreements based on the interests of the disputants.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about negotiation:

## Definition

Negotiation is a dialogue between two or more parties to resolve points of difference, gain an advantage for an individual or collective, or craft outcomes to satisfy various interests.

## Common Applications

People negotiate daily, often without considering it a negotiation. Negotiations may occur in organizations, including businesses, non-profits, and governments, as well as in sales and legal proceedings, and personal situations such as marriage, divorce, parenting, friendship, etc.

## Professional Negotiators

Examples of professional negotiators include union negotiators, leverage buyout negotiators, peace negotiators, and hostage negotiators.

## Negotiation Theory

Negotiation is a specialized and formal version of conflict resolution, most frequently employed when important issues must be agreed upon. Negotiation is necessary when one party requires the other party's agreement to achieve its aim.

## Types of Leverage

There are three types of leverage: positive leverage, negative leverage, and normative leverage. Positive leverage is a negotiator's ability to provide things that his or her opponent wants. Negative leverage is a threat-based form of leverage that represents one side's ability to make the other side worse off. Normative leverage relies on using social standards or norms to encourage consensus.

## Bargaining Approaches

Integrative bargaining (also called "interest-based bargaining," "win-win bargaining") is a negotiation strategy in which parties collaborate to find a "win-win" solution to their dispute. This strategy focuses on developing mutually beneficial agreements based on the interests of the disputants.

I found comprehensive information about auction bidding. Here's an overview based on the search results:

## Basic Definition

An auction is usually a process of buying and selling goods or services by offering them up for bids, taking bids, and then selling the item to the highest bidder or buying the item from the lowest bidder.

## Common Auction Formats

**Open Ascending Price Auction:**
The open ascending price auction is arguably the most common form of auction and has been used throughout history, with participants bidding openly against one another, with each subsequent bid being higher than the previous bid.

**First-Price Sealed-Bid Auction:**
In this type of auction, all bidders simultaneously submit sealed bids so that no bidder knows the bid of any other participant, and the highest bidder pays the price that was submitted.

**Second-Price Sealed-Bid Auctions (Vickrey Auctions):**
These are the same as first-price sealed-bid auctions except that the winner pays a price equal to the second-highest bid. The logic of this auction type is that the dominant strategy for all bidders is to bid their true valuation.

## Modern Applications

The development of the internet has led to a significant rise in the use of auctions, as auctioneers can solicit bids via the internet from a wide range of buyers in a much larger variety of commodities than was previously practical.(no content)These contexts include antiques, paintings, rare collectibles, expensive wines, commodities, livestock, radio spectrum, used cars, real estate, online advertising, vacation packages, emission trading, and many more.

## Auction Theory

Auction theory is a branch of applied economics that deals with how bidders act in auctions and researches how the features of auctions incentivise predictable outcomes.

Matsunaga Institute for Peace and Conflict Resolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spark_M._Matsunaga_Institute_for_Peace_and_Conflict_Resolution"},{"title":"Conflict resolution strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict_resolution_strategy"},{"title":"House of Wisdom for Conflict Resolution & Governance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Wisdom_for_Conflict_Resolution_&_Governance"},{"title":"Peace and conflict studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_and_conflict_studies"},{"title":"Conflict management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict_management"},{"title":"US Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Institute_for_Environmental_Conflict_Resolution"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of conflict resolution:

## Definition and Overview

Conflict resolution is conceptualized as the methods and processes involved in facilitating the peaceful ending of conflict and retribution.

## Approaches and Methods

A wide range of methods and procedures for addressing conflict exist, including negotiation, mediation, mediation-arbitration, diplomacy, and creative peacebuilding.

## Conflict Resolution Styles

The dual concern model of conflict resolution assumes individuals' preferred method of dealing with conflict is based on two underlying themes or dimensions: concern for self (assertiveness) and concern for others (empathy). Group members balance their concern for satisfying personal needs and interests with their concern for satisfying the needs and interests of others in different ways.

The main conflict resolution styles include:

- **Competing/Forcing**: The competitive, "fighting" or forcing conflict style maximizes individual assertiveness and minimizes empathy.

- **Compromising**: The compromising conflict style is typical of individuals who possess an intermediate level of concern for both personal and others' outcomes. Compromisers value fairness and anticipate mutual give-and-take interactions.

- **Collaborating/Problem-solving**: The cooperation, integration, confrontation or problem-solving conflict style is typically used when an individual has elevated interests in their own outcomes as well as in the outcomes of others. During conflict, cooperators collaborate with others in an effort to find an amicable solution that satisfies all parties involved in the conflict.

- **Avoiding and Accommodating**: Yielding, "accommodating", smoothing or suppression conflict styles are characterized by a high level of concern for others and a low level of concern for oneself. This passive pro-social approach emerges when individuals derive personal satisfaction from meeting the needs of others and have a general concern for maintaining stable, positive social relationships.

## Recommended Approach

According to the literature on conflict resolution, a cooperative conflict resolution style is recommended above all others.

Links: [{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"Game Theory (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Theory_(band)"},{"title":"Combinatorial game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_game_theory"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Two-level game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-level_game_theory"},{"title":"Algorithmic game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_game_theory"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Game Theory:

## Definition and Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.(no content)It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

**Nash Equilibrium**: Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

**Types of Games**: A game is cooperative if the players are able to form binding commitments externally enforced (e.g. through contract law). A game is non-cooperative if players cannot form alliances or if all agreements need to be self-enforcing (e.g. through credible threats).

## Recognition and Impact

John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of evolutionary game theory in 1999, and fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Game Theory:

## Definition and Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.(no content)It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

**Nash Equilibrium**: Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

**Types of Games**: A game is cooperative if the players are able to form binding commitments externally enforced (e.g. through contract law). A game is non-cooperative if players cannot form alliances or if all agreements need to be self-enforcing (e.g. through credible threats).

## Recognition and Impact

John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of evolutionary game theory in 1999, and fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

## Search Results: Social Network Analysis

I found comprehensive information about Social Network Analysis. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Core Concepts

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory.(no content)It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

### Applications

Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships. Additionally, social network analysis has found applications in various academic disciplines as well as practical contexts such as countering money laundering and terrorism.

### Visualization

Networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines. These visualizations provide a means of qualitatively assessing networks by varying the visual representation of their nodes and edges to reflect attributes of interest.

### Key Metrics

Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.

### Historical Development

Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim, who wrote about the importance of studying patterns of relationships that connect social actors.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence explaining why it matters)

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence explaining why it matters)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
